source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Poaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: From: Walsh, N.G. (1994). Poaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Spikelets subtended by an involucre of bristles that are free to the base
Spikelets enclosed by a burr-like involucre composed of several rows of spines that are flattened and fused at their bases
Inflorescence of numerous spikelets, fully exserted from upper sheaths; bristles of involucre as long as or longer than spikelets; plants tufted or rhizomatous, not stoloniferous

Inflorescence reduced to one or a few spikelets, remaining enclosed within the uppermost leaf-sheaths; bristles of involucre shorter than spikelets; vigorous weed or lawn-grass, spreading extensively by rhizomes and stolons
At least the inner bristles of involucre ciliate or plumose
Bristles of involucre 20–35 mm long, purplish; spikelets separating from main axis with panicle branch (2–4 mm long) attached; main axis hairy
Bristles of involucre 10–15 mm long, straw-coloured; spikelet separating from main axis immediately below involucre; main axis smooth or scabrous
Inflorescence 8–30 cm long; bristles purplish; lemma of lower (sterile) floret 3-nerved, palea of lower floret lacking; robust, strongly tussock-forming

Inflorescence 3–10 cm long; bristles white or yellowish (rarely purplish); lemma of lower (staminate or sterile) floret 7–9-nerved, palea of lower floret fully developed; long-rhizomatous or weakly tussock-forming
Burr with fewer than 40 spines; largest spines to 4 mm long; all spines flat for their entire length
Burr with more than 40 spines (including basal bristles); longest spines 5 mm or more long and becoming terete toward the apex
